G.L. c. 186 \u00a714.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186 §14, a landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of leased premises is liable for damages.

G.L. c. 185C \u00a73.proposition: Venue is proper in the Boston Housing Court pursuant to G.L. c. 185C §3, as the subject property is located within the Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7410.201.proposition: The heat continued to fluctuate and fall below required levels, in violation of 105 C.M.R. §410.201, requiring a minimum temperature of 68°F between 7:00 A.M. and 11:00 P.M. and 64°F at night from September 15 through June 15.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7410.000 et seq..proposition: Defendant’s actions and failures constitute both a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and a violation of State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. §410.000 et seq.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.raw_text: Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) (landlord liable for tenant’s loss of quiet enjoyment caused by conditions under landlord’s control).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held landlords liable for such interference, including failure to maintain essential services.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that a landlord can be liable for substantial interference with tenants’ quiet enjoyment caused by conditions the landlord created and had the right to control (here, noise from a bar the landlord leased and could regulate). That directly supports the first part of the proposition—landlords’ liability for interference under their control. The opinion does not, however, involve or discuss failure to maintain essential services; that part of the proposition is supported only by other cases cited within this opinion, not by Blackett itself, so the match is partial rather than complete.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (l.raw_text: Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (landlord’s inaction regarding habitability defects constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (l.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held landlords liable for such interference, including failure to maintain essential services.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (l.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, §14 and holds that a landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions—an essential aspect of habitability—constitutes an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. The SJC explicitly rejects an intent requirement for statutory quiet enjoyment and affirms that Gem is liable under §14 because, by failing to maintain sanitary conditions and prevent repeated flooding, it interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. This directly supports the proposition that Massachusetts appellate courts have held landlords liable for interference with quiet enjoyment based on failure to maintain essential services/conditions.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (l.relevant_excerpt:
“Section 14…imposes civil and criminal liability on a landlord that ‘willfully or intentionally’ fails to provide essential services that it is obligated to furnish, or ‘directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.’…
…Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994) (landlord’s duty extends to providing safe and habitable premises).
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held landlords liable for such interference, including failure to maintain essential services.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that Massachusetts appellate courts have held landlords liable for interference with tenants’ rights, including failure to maintain essential services. Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth. expressly *rejects* expanding the warranty of habitability to require provision of security services and affirms summary judgment for the landlord on that claim. While the court does recognize potential liability under the covenant of quiet enjoyment for failing to act against criminal activity, it does not ground that liability in failure to maintain ‘essential services’ and in fact limits the habitability duty to physical facilities, not security or similar services.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the implied warranty of habitability is concerned with the provision, maintenance, and repair of the physical facilities vital to the use of the leased premises, and is not breached solely by the presence on the premises of uninvited persons engaged in unlawful activities or by the failure to provide security services.”

Ahearn v. Stacey, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 678.raw_text: Ahearn v. Stacey, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 678 (1991) (interference includes failure to maintain essential services).
Ahearn v. Stacey, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 678.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held landlords liable for such interference, including failure to maintain essential services.
Ahearn v. Stacey, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 678.case_name: Construction Planners, Inc. v. Dobax Insurance Agency, Inc.
Ahearn v. Stacey, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 678.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns an insurance broker’s duty (or lack of duty) to renew an insurance policy and the existence of “special circumstances” creating such a duty. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, interference with quiet enjoyment, or failure to maintain essential services, nor does it mention Ahearn v. Stacey. Therefore it does not support the proposition that Massachusetts appellate courts have held landlords liable for interference including failure to maintain essential services.
Ahearn v. Stacey, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 678.relevant_excerpt: "The issue raised in this appeal is whether sufficient special circumstances were shown to take the case out of the general rule that an insurance broker owes his client no duty to renew a policy of insurance absent a specific request or undertaking to do so."

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).raw_text: Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) (quiet enjoyment breach does not require malicious intent).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held landlords liable for such interference, including failure to maintain essential services.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The proposition is that Massachusetts appellate courts have held landlords liable under the quiet enjoyment statute for interferences including failure to maintain essential services. In discussing the standard of fault under G.L. c. 186, § 14, the SJC in Al‑Ziab expressly reaffirms prior cases (Simon, Cruz, Darmetko, Dorgan) where landlords were held liable for failing to repair or maintain habitable conditions, characterizing such failures as violations of § 14. That reasoning directly supports the proposition that landlords can be liable for interference based on failure to maintain essential services/conditions, even though this particular case concerns lead paint and ultimately finds no § 14 liability on these facts.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (heat failures support claim under §14).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held landlords liable for such interference, including failure to maintain essential services.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The Appeals Court squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat—a core essential service—constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and that financial inability is not a defense. The court orders declaratory, injunctive, and damages relief under § 14 based on that failure to furnish heat. This directly supports the proposition that Massachusetts appellate courts have held landlords liable for interference with quiet enjoyment through failure to maintain essential services.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’… On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14; (b) an injunction…; and (c) an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771 (1994) (tenant may recover for interference with use and enjoyment of dwelling).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held landlords liable for such interference, including failure to maintain essential services.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that a tenant may recover substantial damages against a landlord for breach of the implied warranty of habitability where there are serious defects, including lack of heat and vermin infestation, but it does not frame this as ‘interference with use and enjoyment’ nor focus on ‘failure to maintain essential services’ as a separate doctrinal ground. The court also notes that the trial judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment but awarded no damages on that claim, and the appeal concerns only the measure of habitability damages. Thus, while factually consistent with the proposition, the case is not authority for landlord liability specifically for interference with use and enjoyment or failure to maintain essential services as such.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: “Wideman’s tenancy with Cruz Management commenced on or about May 18, 1988… During her tenancy, she and her two sons endured continuing infestations of rodents and cockroaches. Heat in the apartment ranged from nonexistent (at worst) to insufficient (at best). … Most of the violations remained uncorrected through October, 1990, when Wideman finally vacated. … The judge rendered a written decision in Wideman’s favor concluding, among other things, that conditions in her apartment had been in breach of the implied warranty of habitability, and that the value of the apartment had been reduced by fifty per cent.”

Meadow Hill Estates, Inc. v. Branscombe,.raw_text: Meadow Hill Estates, Inc. v. Branscombe, 593 N.E.2d 1379 (Mass. App. Ct. 1992) (landlord’s inadequate heat supports damages).
Meadow Hill Estates, Inc. v. Branscombe,.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held landlords liable for such interference, including failure to maintain essential services.
Meadow Hill Estates, Inc. v. Branscombe,.support_reasoning: The provided opinion concerns an Ohio probate court’s subject matter and personal jurisdiction, fee-splitting between attorneys, and contempt for failure to comply with an order related to ward settlement proceeds. It does not involve Massachusetts law, landlord‑tenant relationships, or failure to maintain essential services such as heat. Therefore it cannot support the proposition that the Massachusetts SJC or Appeals Court have held landlords liable for interference including failure to maintain essential services.
Meadow Hill Estates, Inc. v. Branscombe,.relevant_excerpt: "At the core of this case is the requirement that a probate court maintain control over any personal injury settlement entered into on behalf of the ward under the probate court’s protection... We hold that a probate court, in order to maintain control over any personal injury settlement entered into on behalf of a ward under its protection, has subject matter jurisdiction over the entire amount of settlement funds, which includes attorney fees to be drawn therefrom."

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (recognizing duty to maintain habitability included in tenancy).
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held landlords liable for such interference, including failure to maintain essential services.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: This opinion (a concurrence/dissent in Hemingway) recognizes an implied obligation to keep premises habitable and ties that obligation to compliance with the State Sanitary Code, but it is focused on limits on tenants’ rent liability and defenses in summary process, not on landlord liability for interference with tenancy such as failure to maintain essential services. It does not clearly hold landlords “liable for such interference” in the affirmative-remedies sense suggested by the proposition; rather, it discusses implied obligations and rent abatement, and in any event is not the majority holding. Thus it does not support the proposition as stated.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005) (persistent defects causing discomfort establish breach).
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held landlords liable for such interference, including failure to maintain essential services.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that Massachusetts appellate courts have held landlords liable for interference with tenants’ quiet enjoyment, including failures to maintain essential services. In this case, however, the Appeals Court affirms findings that there was no breach of the warranty of habitability and no breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, because the landlord promptly repaired conditions and there was no serious interference. The opinion discusses the legal standards but does not impose liability on the landlord; it is thus not supporting authority for landlord liability in such circumstances.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions… The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred. We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises… [W]e… conclude… that she did not err in ruling that there was no breach of the warranty of habitability applicable to Casey’s premises.”
